skill.name: pennylane
skill.description: Cross-platform Python library for quantum computing, quantum machine learning, and quantum chemistry. Enables building and training quantum circuits with automatic differentiation, seamless integration with PyTorch/JAX/TensorFlow, and device-independent execution across simulators and quantum hardware (IBM, Amazon Braket, Google, Rigetti, IonQ, etc.). Use when working with quantum circuits, variational quantum algorithms (VQE, QAOA), quantum neural networks, hybrid quantum-classical models, molecular simulations, quantum chemistry calculations, or any quantum computing tasks requiring gradient-based optimization, hardware-agnostic programming, or quantum machine learning workflows.
skill.summary: Cross-platform Python library for quantum computing, quantum machine learning, and quantum chemistry...
skill.author: K-Dense Inc.

security_audit.summary: Files are documentation and examples only. No code reads local credentials, environment variables, or performs network calls. Behavior matches the stated educational purpose.

content.value_statement: Quantum workflows are hard to design, optimize, and debug across devices. This skill provides clear PennyLane patterns for circuits, QML, and chemistry.
actual_capabilities: Explain and compose quantum circuits with gates, measurements, and dynamic control.
Design hybrid QML models and integrate with PyTorch, JAX, or TensorFlow.
Set up simulators and hardware plugins with device configuration guidance.
Build quantum chemistry workflows with VQE and molecular Hamiltonians.
Apply optimization methods and gradient strategies for variational circuits.
Use templates, transforms, noise models, and resource estimation patterns.
limitations: Requires PennyLane and any device plugins installed locally.
Hardware access needs provider accounts and API tokens.
Large circuits can be slow or memory heavy on simulators.
Does not guarantee experimental accuracy on real hardware.

use_cases.title: Prototype variational circuits
use_cases.description: Draft circuit structures, select gradients, and estimate resources before running experiments.

use_cases.title: Add a quantum layer
use_cases.description: Integrate a QNode with PyTorch or TensorFlow and design a training loop.

use_cases.title: Explore VQE workflows
use_cases.description: Build a molecular Hamiltonian and plan a ground state energy experiment.

prompt_templates.title: First circuit
prompt_templates.prompt: Create a two qubit PennyLane circuit with RX and CNOT, return an expectation value, and explain each step briefly.

prompt_templates.title: Hybrid model plan
prompt_templates.prompt: Show how to wrap a QNode as a PyTorch layer for binary classification and list the key training steps.

prompt_templates.title: VQE outline
prompt_templates.prompt: Outline a VQE workflow for H2 with UCCSD, including Hamiltonian setup and optimizer choice.

prompt_templates.title: Device strategy
prompt_templates.prompt: Compare default.qubit, lightning.qubit, and a hardware backend for a 12 qubit circuit and suggest a run plan.

output_examples.input: Plan a small variational classifier in PennyLane for a four feature dataset.
output: Choose angle encoding on four wires for the features.
Use a two layer hardware efficient ansatz with RY and CNOT.
Train with Adam and monitor loss every 10 epochs.
Validate on default.qubit before hardware runs.

best_practices: Start with default.qubit before hardware runs.
Use parameter shift when running on hardware devices.
Profile circuit depth and parameters with qml.specs.
anti_patterns: Run large circuits without estimating memory and depth.
Use amplitude encoding without normalizing input data.
Switch ML interfaces without matching the framework.

faq.question: Which PennyLane versions are supported?
faq.answer: It follows the installed PennyLane version in your environment.

faq.question: What are the limits on circuit size?
faq.answer: Simulator limits depend on memory and qubit count. Large circuits can be slow.

faq.question: How does it integrate with ML frameworks?
faq.answer: It provides examples for PyTorch, JAX, and TensorFlow interfaces.

faq.question: Does it access my local data or keys?
faq.answer: No. The files are static documentation and examples only.

faq.question: What if a QNode fails to run?
faq.answer: Check device selection, wire counts, and parameter shapes, then retry on a simulator.

faq.question: How does it compare to Qiskit guides?
faq.answer: It focuses on PennyLane features like QNodes, autodiff, and hybrid models.
